abstracts.cdata!:
This project is rated as highly
            satisfactory. This rating is based on the fact that all
            critical objectives were attained and this was done in the
            face of numerous technical, institutional, ad political
            obstacles. Given the difficult context in which
            implementation occurred this is a considerable achievement.
            The following lessons have been learned: There must be
            strong ownership by and good dialogue with the Borrower and
            its constituent organizations if necessary implementation
            decisions are to be taken on a timely basis. Capacity
            building takes a long time, requires much patience, and
            requires a disproportionate commitment of Bank staff time
            and supervision resources. There is an inherent tension
            between the need to build capacity and the need to get the
            job done. However, the longer-term systemic issues should
            not be overlooked. Adequate "slack" time must be
            provided for if the vicissitudes of border closures )
            political risks) are to be weathered. The provision of
            operating support to implementing units is critical to
            establishing managerial and technical capacity. Close
            on-the-ground supervision and willingness to be flexible in
            adapting the project to local realities is essential. It can
            also contribute significantly to mitigating risks. Finally,
            it has been demonstrated that senior management's
            decision to decentralize responsibilities to the field can
            yield significant benefits.
